Title: The Big Sleep
Description: Private detective Philip Marlowe is hired by a wealthy family. Before the complex case is over, he's seen murder, blackmail, and what might be love.

Genre.Name: Film Noir
Genre.Description: Film noir is a cinematic term used primarily to describe stylish Hollywood crime dramas, particularly those that emphasize cynical attitudes and motivations.

Director.Name: Howard Hawks
Director.Bio: Howard Winchester Hawks was an American film director, producer and screenwriter of the classic Hollywood era. A versatile film director, Hawks explored many genres such as comedies, dramas, gangster films, science fiction, film noir, war films and westerns.

Title: The Big Sleep
Description: Private detective Philip Marlowe is hired by a wealthy family. Before the complex case is over, he's seen murder, blackmail, and what might be love.

Genre.Name: Film Noir
Genre.Description: Film noir is a cinematic term used primarily to describe stylish Hollywood crime dramas, particularly those that emphasize cynical attitudes and motivations.

Director.Name: Howard Hawks
Director.Bio: Howard Winchester Hawks was an American film director, producer and screenwriter of the classic Hollywood era. A versatile film director, Hawks explored many genres such as comedies, dramas, gangster films, science fiction, film noir, war films and westerns.

Title: The Third Man
Description: Pulp novelist Holly Martins travels to shadowy, postwar Vienna, only to find himself investigating the mysterious death of an old friend, Harry Lime.

Genre.Name: Film Noir
Genre.Description: Film noir is a cinematic term used primarily to describe stylish Hollywood crime dramas, particularly those that emphasize cynical attitudes and motivations.

Director.Name: Carol Reed
Director.Bio: Sir Carol Reed was an English film director and producer, best known for Odd Man Out (1947), The Fallen Idol (1948), The Third Man (1949), and Oliver! (1968), for which he was awarded the Academy Award for Best Director.

Title: Touch of Evil
Description: A stark, perverse story of murder, kidnapping, and police corruption in a Mexican border town.

Genre.Name: Film Noir
Genre.Description: Film noir is a cinematic term used primarily to describe stylish Hollywood crime dramas, particularly those that emphasize cynical attitudes and motivations.

Director.Name: Orson Welles
Director.Bio: George Orson Welles was an American actor, director, producer, and screenwriter who is remembered for his innovative work in film, radio and theatre. He is considered to be among the greatest and most influential filmmakers of all time.

Title: Drive
Description: A mysterious Hollywood action film stuntman who moonlights as a getaway driver, gets in trouble with gangsters when he tries to help his neighbor's husband rob a pawn shop while serving as his getaway driver.

Genre.Name: Neon-Noir
Genre.Description: Accentuating the use of artificial and neon lighting in the films-noir of the '40s and '50s, neon-noir films accentuate this aesthetic with electrifying color and manipulated light in order to highlight their socio-cultural critiques and their references to contemporary and pop culture. In doing so, neon-noir films present the themes of urban decay, consumerist decadence and capitalism, existentialism, sexuality, and issues of race and violence in the contemporary culture, not only in America, but the globalized world at large.

Director.Name: Nicholas Winding Refn
Director.Bio: Nicolas Winding Refn is a Danish film director, screenwriter, and producer. He is known for his collaborations with Mads Mikkelsen, Tom Hardy and Ryan Gosling.

Title: Le Samourai
Description: After professional hitman Jef Costello is seen by witnesses his efforts to provide himself an alibi drive him further into a corner.

Genre.Name: Neo-Noir
Genre.Description: Neo-noir is a revival of film noir, a genre that had originally flourished during the post-World War II era in the United States—roughly from 1940 to 1960. The French term, film noir, translates literally to English as 'black film', indicating sinister stories often presented in a shadowy cinematographic style. Neo-noir has a similar style but with updated themes, content, style, and visual elements.

Director.Name: Jean-Pierre Melville
Director.Bio: Born Jean-Pierre Grumbach, he was a French filmmaker and actor. Among his films are Le Silence de la mer (1949), Bob le flambeur (1956), Le Doulos (1962), Le Samouraï (1967), Army of Shadows (1969) and Le Cercle Rouge (1970). While with the French Resistance during World War II, he adopted the pseudonym Melville as a tribute to his favorite American author Herman Melville. He kept it as his stage name once the war was over.

Bio: Born Jean-Pierre Grumbach, he was a French filmmaker and actor. While with the French Resistance during World War II, he adopted the pseudonym Melville as a tribute to his favorite American author Herman Melville. He kept it as his stage name once the war was over.

Title: Le Cercle Rouge
Description: After leaving prison, master thief Corey crosses paths with a notorious escapee and an alcoholic former policeman. The trio proceed to plot an elaborate heist.

Genre.Name: Neo-Noir
Genre.Description: Neo-noir is a revival of film noir, a genre that had originally flourished during the post-World War II era in the United States—roughly from 1940 to 1960. The French term, film noir, translates literally to English as 'black film', indicating sinister stories often presented in a shadowy cinematographic style. Neo-noir has a similar style but with updated themes, content, style, and visual elements.

Director.Name: Jean-Pierre Melville
Director.Bio: Born Jean-Pierre Grumbach, he was a French filmmaker and actor. Among his films are Le Silence de la mer (1949), Bob le flambeur (1956), Le Doulos (1962), Le Samouraï (1967), Army of Shadows (1969) and Le Cercle Rouge (1970). While with the French Resistance during World War II, he adopted the pseudonym Melville as a tribute to his favorite American author Herman Melville. He kept it as his stage name once the war was over.

Bio: Born Jean-Pierre Grumbach, he was a French filmmaker and actor. While with the French Resistance during World War II, he adopted the pseudonym Melville as a tribute to his favorite American author Herman Melville. He kept it as his stage name once the war was over.

Title: Blade Runner
Description: A blade runner, a type of futuristic cop, must pursue and terminate four replicants who stole a ship in space and have returned to Earth to find their creator.

Genre.Name: Neon-Noir
Genre.Description: Accentuating the use of artificial and neon lighting in the films-noir of the '40s and '50s, neon-noir films accentuate this aesthetic with electrifying color and manipulated light in order to highlight their socio-cultural critiques and their references to contemporary and pop culture. In doing so, neon-noir films present the themes of urban decay, consumerist decadence and capitalism, existentialism, sexuality, and issues of race and violence in the contemporary culture, not only in America, but the globalized world at large.

Director.Name: Ridley Scott
Director.Bio: Sir Ridley Scott is an English film director and producer. Directing, among others, science fiction films, his work is known for its atmospheric and highly concentrated visual style

Title: In A Lonely Place
Description: A potentially violent screenwriter is a murder suspect until his lovely neighbor clears him. However, she soon starts to have her doubts.

Genre.Name: Film Noir
Genre.Description: Film noir is a cinematic term used primarily to describe stylish Hollywood crime dramas, particularly those that emphasize cynical attitudes and motivations.

Director.Name: Nicholas Ray
Director.Bio: Nicholas Ray (born Raymond Nicholas Kienzle Jr.,) was an American film director, screenwriter, and actor best known for the 1955 film Rebel Without a Cause. Ray's compositions within the CinemaScope frame and use of color are particularly well-regarded and he was an important influence on the French New Wave,

Title: Croupier
Description: An aspiring writer is hired as a croupier at a casino, where he realizes that his life as a croupier would make a great novel.

Genre.Name: Pulp-Noir
Genre.Description: Pulp noir is a subgenre influenced by various 'noir' genres, as well as (as implied by its name) pulp fiction genres; particularly the hard-boiled genres which help give rise to film noir. Pulp noir is marked by its use of classic noir techniques, but with urban influences.

Director.Name: Mike Hodges
Director.Bio: Michael Tommy Hodges is an English screenwriter, film and television director, playwright and novelist.

Title: Se7en
Description: Two detectives, a rookie and a veteran, hunt a serial killer who uses the seven deadly sins as his motives.

Genre.Name: Neo-Noir
Genre.Description: Neo-noir is a revival of film noir, a genre that had originally flourished during the post-World War II era in the United States—roughly from 1940 to 1960. The French term, film noir, translates literally to English as 'black film', indicating sinister stories often presented in a shadowy cinematographic style. Neo-noir has a similar style but with updated themes, content, style, and visual elements.

Director.Name: David Fincher
Director.Bio: David Andrew Leo Fincher is an American film director. His films, mostly psychological thrillers and biographical dramas, have received 40 nominations at the Academy Awards, including three for him as Best Director.
